content.text: Initially, the tank is empty
Calculate the depth of water in the tank after 1.00 minute. Give your answer to three significant figures
The height of the water decreases by \(0.420 \text{m}\) as it flows down the channel
Calculate the decrease in gravitational potential energy of the water each second
decrease in gravitational potential energy =   .........
The water stops flowing. The depth of water in the tank is \(0.800 \text{m}\)
Calculate the pressure at the bottom of the tank due to the water
pressure =   .........

Fig. 1.1 shows sea water flowing down a channel into a tank without splashing. The water is flowing at a rate of \(800 \text{kg} /\text{min}\). The length and width of the tank are \(3.10 \text{m}\) and \(1.20 \text{m}\). The density of the sea water is \(1020 \text{kg} /\text{m}^3\)
Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)
A pendulum swings with a time period of approximately one second
Describe how to use a stop-watch to determine the time period of the pendulum
Complete Table 2.1 by writing in each space of the right-hand column which **one** of the following devices is used to measure the quantity in the left-hand column
digital balance measuring cylinder metre rule
micrometer screw gauge stop-watch thermocouple

table.html:
quantitydevice
volume of water in a glass
width of a small swimming pool
thickness of a piece of aluminium foil

content.text: State one other source of power which derives its energy from the Sun
State one source of power which does not derive its energy from the Sun
Tidal power derives most of its energy from the Moon and part of its energy from the Sun
Explain whether this method of generation of electrical power is renewable

The mass of water passing through the turbine each second is \(6.0 \times 10^{3} \text{kg}\). The speed of the water is \(2.0 \text{m/s}\). \(40\%\) of the kinetic energy of the water is converted to electrical energy
Calculate the electrical power generated
Fig. 3.1 shows a small water turbine driven by a tidal flow of water to generate electrical power
Explain, in terms of the momentum of particles, how a gas exerts a pressure
The temperature of a sample of gas is increased at constant volume
State and explain any change in the pressure of the gas

Another sample of gas is in a sealed container of volume \(170 \text{cm}^3\) and exerts a pressure of \(9.0 \times 10^4 \text{Pa}\). The volume of the container decreases by \(70 \text{cm}^3\) at constant temperature
Calculate the new pressure of the gas
pressure =   .........
The mass of the block is \(1200\mathrm{kg}\) and it is heated in the furnace from \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(380^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The aluminium block does not melt
The specific heat capacity of aluminium is \(960 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \text{Â°C})\)
Calculate the thermal energy gained by the block in the furnace
thermal energy =   .........
Fig. 5.1 shows a factory worker standing \(3\mathrm{m}\) from the block
State and explain the main process by which thermal energy is transferred to the worker
State and explain the main process by which thermal energy is transferred from the outer surface of the solid metal rollers to their interior
Fig. 5.1 shows an aluminium block after leaving a furnace in a factory
On Fig. 6.1, carefully draw two rays from X which locate the image of the object. Draw the image and label it IY
Measure the distance from IY along the principal axis to the centre line of the lens
State two reasons why the image IY is virtual
Fig. 6.1 shows a converging lens and an object OX. The focuses of the lens are labelled F
Fig. 6.2 shows a ray of green light passing into, through and out of a glass prism
A ray of blue light is incident on the prism on the same path as the incident ray of green light
On Fig. 6.2, draw the path of the blue light through and out of the prism
Fig. 7.2 shows a magnet, labelled magnet 1, placed on position 1
On Fig. 7.2, draw lines to show the pattern of the magnetic field produced by magnet 1. Place arrows on the lines to show the direction of the field.
Magnet 1 is removed from position 1. Fig. 7.3 shows another magnet, labelled magnet 2, placed on position 2
On Fig. 7.3, draw, at the right-hand end of position 1, a line with an arrow to show the direction of the magnetic field produced by magnet 2.
State the direction of the force that the N pole of magnet 2 exerts on the N pole of magnet 1
Justify your answer to (c)(i)
Fig. 7.4 shows magnet 1 placed on position 1 and magnet 2 placed on position 2
This question is about the magnetic fields around bar magnets. Fig. 7.1 shows two positions used by a student doing an experiment
The light intensity at the circuit increases from dark to bright
State any effect on the resistance of component Y
State and explain any effect on the reading of the voltmeter
Calculate the number of electrons that pass through the resistor each second
Calculate the power dissipated by the resistor
The circuit shown in Fig. 8.2 is switched on for \(2.0 \text{min}\)
The current in the \(4.0 \Omega\) resistor is \(3.0 \text{A}\) and the magnitude of the charge on an electron is \(1.6 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\)
Fig. 8.1 shows an electrical circuit
a diode
a NOT gate
Draw the symbol for:
Fig. 9.1 shows a digital circuit
Complete the truth table shown in Table 9.1
State another single gate which is equivalent to the part of the circuit between \(\mathrm{I}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{Z}\)
Using two logic gates, design and draw a digital circuit with two inputs and two outputs which has the truth table shown in Table 9.2
Use either the usual logic gate symbols or correctly labelled square boxes in your diagram
State the proton number and nucleon number of an \(\alpha\) (alpha)-particle
proton number
nucleon number
Determine the magnitude of the charge of an \(\alpha\) (alpha)-particle
charge
The magnitude of the charge on a \(\beta\) (beta)-particle is \(1.6 \times 10^{-19} \text{C}\)

A nucleus of radium-230 consists of 88 protons and 142 neutrons. Radium-230 is radioactive and decays by \(\beta\) (beta)-emission to an isotope of actinium. The symbol for radium is Ra and the symbol for actinium is Ac
Write down the nuclide equation for this decay
The half-life of radium-230 is \(93 \text{min.}\) A sample contains \(9.6 \times 10^{-12} \text{g}\) of radium-230
Calculate the mass of radium in the sample after 279 min
